STM 0.0.0.9000
  • Reference
  • Changelog

Progression table

progression_table.Rd

Progression table explained in the 'Strength Training Manual' Chapter 6.

percMR_step(
  reps,
  step = 0,
  volume = "normal",
  type = "grinding",
  adjustment = 0,
  func_max_perc_1RM = get_max_perc_1RM_percMR
)

RIR_increment(
  reps,
  step = 0,
  volume = "normal",
  type = "grinding",
  adjustment = 0,
  func_max_perc_1RM = get_max_perc_1RM
)

RIR_increment_fixed_2(
  reps,
  step = 0,
  volume = "normal",
  type = "grinding",
  adjustment = 0,
  func_max_perc_1RM = get_max_perc_1RM
)

RIR_increment_fixed_4(
  reps,
  step = 0,
  volume = "normal",
  type = "grinding",
  adjustment = 0,
  func_max_perc_1RM = get_max_perc_1RM
)

perc_drop(
  reps,
  step = 0,
  volume = "normal",
  type = "grinding",
  adjustment = 0,
  func_max_perc_1RM = get_max_perc_1RM
)

perc_drop_fixed_5(
  reps,
  step = 0,
  volume = "normal",
  type = "grinding",
  adjustment = 0,
  func_max_perc_1RM = get_max_perc_1RM
)

perc_drop_fixed_25(
  reps,
  step = 0,
  volume = "normal",
  type = "grinding",
  adjustment = 0,
  func_max_perc_1RM = get_max_perc_1RM
)

generate_progression_table(
  progression_table = RIR_increment,
  type = c("grinding", "ballistic"),
  volume = c("intensive", "normal", "extensive"),
  reps = 1:12,
  step = seq(-3, 0, 1),
  ...
)

relInt(
  reps,
  step = 0,
  volume = "normal",
  type = "grinding",
  adjustment = 0,
  func_max_perc_1RM = get_max_perc_1RM_relInt
)

Arguments

reps

Number of reps
step

Progression step. Default is 0. Use negative numbers (i.e., -1, -2)
volume

Character string: 'intensive', 'normal' (Default), or 'extensive'
type

Type of max rep table. Options are grinding (Default) and ballistic.
adjustment

Additional adjustment. Default is 0.
func_max_perc_1RM

What max rep table should be used? Default is get_max_perc_1RM
progression_table

Progression table function to use. Default is RIR_increment
...

Forwarded to progression_table for using different rep max function

Value

List with two elements: adjustment and perc_1RM

Functions

  • percMR_step: %MR Step progression table

  • RIR_increment: RIR Increment progression table. This is the original progression table from the Strength Training Manual

  • RIR_increment_fixed_2: Fixed 2 RIR Increment progression table. This variant have fixed RIR increment across reps from phases to phases (2RIR) and 2RIR difference between extensive, normal, and intensive schemes

  • RIR_increment_fixed_4: Fixed 4 RIR Increment progression table. This variant have fixed RIR increment across reps from phases to phases (4RIR) and 4RIR difference between extensive, normal, and intensive schemes

  • perc_drop: Percent Drop progression table. This is the original progression table from the Strength Training Manual

  • perc_drop_fixed_5: 5% Fixed Percent Drop progression table. This variant have fixed percent drops across reps from phases to phases (5%) and 5% difference between extensive, normal, and intensive schemes

  • perc_drop_fixed_25: 2.5% Fixed Percent Drop progression table. This variant have fixed percent drops across reps from phases to phases (2.5%) and 2.5% difference between extensive, normal, and intensive schemes

  • generate_progression_table: Generates progression tables

  • relInt: Relative Intensity progression table

Examples

percMR_step(10, step = seq(-3, 0, 1))

#> $adjustment
#> [1] 0.55 0.65 0.75 0.85
#> 
#> $perc_1RM
#> [1] 0.6228766 0.6612411 0.6925208 0.7185123
#> 
percMR_step(10, step = seq(-3, 0, 1), volume = "extensive")

#> $adjustment
#> [1] 0.4 0.5 0.6 0.7
#> 
#> $perc_1RM
#> [1] 0.5457026 0.6002401 0.6430868 0.6776379
#> 
percMR_step(5, step = seq(-3, 0, 1), type = "ballistic")

#> $adjustment
#> [1] 0.55 0.65 0.75 0.85
#> 
#> $perc_1RM
#> [1] 0.6228766 0.6612411 0.6925208 0.7185123
#> 

# Generate progression table
generate_progression_table(percMR_step)

# Plot progression table
plot_progression_table(percMR_step)

plot_progression_table(percMR_step, "adjustment")

RIR_increment(10, step = seq(-3, 0, 1))

#> $adjustment
#> [1] 8.090909 6.272727 4.454545 2.636364
#> 
#> $perc_1RM
#> [1] 0.6240533 0.6485581 0.6750661 0.7038333
#> 
RIR_increment(10, step = seq(-3, 0, 1), volume = "extensive")

#> $adjustment

#> [1] 16 12  8  4
